subtasks: Choose appropriate time for germination based on location and growing method
Soak chili seeds in water for 24 hours to soften coating
Place seeds in a moist paper towel or peat pellet
Keep seeds in a warm location for 2 weeks
For indoor growing, place seedlings on a warm sunny windowsill
For outdoor growing, place seedlings in a heated greenhouse
Maintain evenly moist soil, avoiding overwatering to prevent fungus
Acclimatize outdoor chili plants gradually over 7-10 days
Transplant seedlings into well-prepared fertile, moist, well-drained soil
Consider growing chilies in pots under cover in warm greenhouses or polytunnels
Monitor indoor plants in grow lights, extending the growing season
Move chili plants to larger containers as they grow bigger
Prune chili plants by removing growing tips of flowering shoots
Apply organic high-nitrogen fertilizer after pruning to promote recovery
Harvest chili peppers when mature, whether green or colored, as they reach adequate size
Monitor chilies for early signs of disease or pests
